colours is confirmed by observations of considerable accuracy, and 
that it involves mathematically the theory of three elements of 
colour; but that the disposition of the colours on the circumference 
of a circle was only a provisional arrangement, and that the 
true relations of the colours of the spectrum can only be determined 
by direct observation. 
<u>Young<\u>* appears to have originated the theory, that the three 
elements of colour are determined as much by the constitution 
of the sense of sight as by anything external to us. He conceives 
that three different sensations may be excited by light, but 
that the proportion in which each of the three is excited 
depends on the nature of the light. <s>E<\s> He <s>makes<\s> conjectures that 
these primary sensations correspond to red, green, and violet. 
A blue ray, though homogeneous in itself, he conceives capable 
of exciting both the green and the violet sensation, and therefore 
he would call blue a compound colour, though the colour of 
a simple kind of light. The <u>quality<\u> of any colour depends, according 
to this theory, on the ratios of the intensities of the three sensations 
which it excites, and its <u>brightness<\u> depends on the sum of these 
three intensities. 
<u>Sir David Brewster<\u>,+ in his "New Analysis of the Solar 
Light" has represented by three curves, the intensities of 
three primary colours in different parts of the spectrum. 
The base line of these curves represents the length of the spectrum, and the 
ordinates represent the intensities of the three colours at each 
point. The primaries adopted by him are red, <s>blue,<\s> yellow and 
blue, but we shall find that any three different colours may 
be selected as standards of reference, and <s>therefore<\s> that there is no 
real difference in the results, whatever standards we adopt.
